choices.text: Pulmonary infection is the most common

questions.text: Which statement is not true regarding the melioidosis?
questions.solution:
B. pseudomallei is GNB, oxidase positive non-fermenters.

  • Bipolar stained (safety pin appearance)
  • Intrinsic Resistant to polymyxin B

Melioidosis is contracted by inoculated soil and water through wounds or inhalation and is particularly common during and after the wet season.

Melioidosis Clinical feature:

  • Pulmonary infection: Ranges from abscesses, pneumonia or severe necrotizing lung disease to chronic pulmonary tuberculosis.
  • Skin ulceration & Lymphadenopathy
  • Recently caused Neuro- Melioidosis in India (rare and severe manifestation)
  • This disease is also called 'Vietnam time-bomb'.
  • Bioterrorism: B. pseudomallei can be used as a potential agent of biological warfare.
  • Ashdown medium is used as a selective medium.

choices.text: Food poisoning due to preformed toxin

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with headache, nausea, diarrhoea and an erythematous blanching rash about 60 minutes after eating tuna fish at a restaurant in Goa. She also complained of pruritus and a restless feeling. Her face became flushed soon after her meal. Her friend who also ate tuna had similar symptoms. What would be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Scombroid poisoning results from eating contaminated fish that have been improperly stored after being caught. The primary toxic agent implicated in scombroid poisoning is histidine (normally found in dark fish meat), which breaks down to histamine. In temperatures warmer than 4 C, the fish undergo bacterial overgrowth and subsequently convert histidine to histamine. In properly stored fish, histamine is normally less than 0.1 mg per 100 g, but histamine levels in contaminated fish are at least 20 to 50 mg per 100 g of fish.

Responsible bacteria: Morganella morganii, Escherichia coli, Vibrio, Proteus,Klebsiella, Clostridium, Salmonella, and Shigella.

Scombroid occurs worldwide and is one of most common fish poisonings. Scombroid poisoning can occur from eating tuna, mackerel, mahi-mahi (dolphin fish), sardines, anchovies, herring, bluefish, amberjack, and marlin.

Symptoms include flushing, rash, urticaria (generally widespread erythema, usually lacking wheals), palpitations, headache, dizziness, sweating, and burning of the mouth and throat. Gastrointestinal symptoms can include abdominal cramps, nausea, vomiting and diarrhoea.

choices.text: Skirrows media, microaerophilic condition & 42 degree C
Wilson blair media, normal aerophilic condition & 37 degree C
TCBS media, normal aerophilic condition & 37 degree C
Campy BAP media, normal aerophilic condition & 37 degree C

questions.text: A 45yrs old patient was provisionally diagnosed GBS. The stool sample sent to the micro lab for the isolation of C. jejuni. What should be culture requirement?
questions.solution:
• Campylobacter jejuni are motile (darting motility), non-sporing, microaerophilic (5% O2), curved gram-negative rods show catalase & oxidase positive.
  • Commonly associated with Inflammatory diarrhoea.
  • Causes reactive arthritis and other rheumatologic manifestations in persons with the HLA-B27 phenotype.
  • Guillain -Barre syndrome (mainly by Jejuni serotype 0 19).
  • Selective media used for isolation of Jejuni are: Skirrow's, Butzler's, Campy BAP.
  • Growth at 42°C: Thermophilic Campylobacter species (C. jejuni, C coli and C. lari) can be differentiated from C. fetus, which is non-thermophilic.

choices.text: Ceftriaxone should be reported instead of cefazolin
Clindamycin should be reported for inducible resistance prior to reporting
Cefazolin result should be changed to resistant since the oxacillin is resistant
Cotrimoxazole result should be removed since all S aureus are resistant

questions.text:
A 50 yrs old farmer was diagnosed with osteomyelitis and his blood culture was positive and subculture on blood agar showed growth of beta haemolytic, golden yellow pigmented bacteria. AST was done with following results:

What should the microbiologist do next?
questions.solution:
MRSA is mediated by a chromosomally coded gene called mecA gene, which alters penicillin-binding protein (PBP) present on S. aureus cell membrane 10 PBP-2a.

Altered PBP2a of MRSA strains has less affinity for beta lactam antibiotics; hence, MRSA strains are resistant to all beta lactam antibiotics (Penicillins, Cephalosporins upto 4th generation, Carbapenems).

Cefazolin is a 1st G Cephalosporin therefore it must be reported resistant in case of MRSA reporting irrespective of its sensitivity status invitro (AST).

Detection of MRSA:

  1. cefoxitin or oxacillin discs by Disc diffusion test
  2. Oxacillin screening agar
  3. PCR detecting mecA gene

questions.text: A 38-years-old rice farmer from UP presented with history of high-grade fever for 7 days and altered sensorium for 2 days. On examination, He had conjunctival haemorrhage & jaundice. Urgent investigations showed haemoglobin of 11 gm/dl, serum bilirubin 8 mg/dl and urea 78 mg/dl. Peripheral blood smear was negative for malarial parasite and blood culture was also negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
It is a case of leptospirosis and it is cause by spirochete Leptospira interrogans.

Leptospirosis is related to 3R's: rodents, rainfall and rice field.

Weil's disease: Severe leptospirosis:

  • High grade fever
  • Jaundice and raised liver enzymes
  • Haemorrhages: Pulmonary (MC)
  • Kidney: Raised serum urea and creatinine

Lab diagnosis:

  • Specimens: CSF and blood (in first 10 days of infection) and urine (between 10-30 days of infection)
  • Microscopy: Leptospira are extremely thin, hence seen under dark ground microscope.
  • Isolation: Leptospira takes 4-6 weeks to grow in EMJH medium, Korthof's media and Fletcher's media.
  • Microscopic agglutination test (MAT) detects antibodies against specific serovars of interrogans. It is the gold standard method and reference test for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.
  • RTPCR

questions.text: A 35yrs old fire fighter patient presented with 55% burns on his hands and legs. There was a green colored pus discharge from burn wounds as shown in given image. What would be the probable causative agent of this infection?
questions.solution:
Coloured pus is a characteristic feature of Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection as its produced diffusible pigment. Pigments produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa are:

  1. Pyocyanin (Bluish-green)
  2. Pyoverdine / Fluorescein): Greenish-yellow
  3. Pyorubin (Red)
  4. Pyomelanin (Brownish-black)

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a non-fermenter, obligate aerobe, motile, catalase +, oxidase + GNB.

MC Infections caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa are:

  1. Skin and soft tissue infections
  2. VAP
  3. UTI
  4. LRT infection in cystic fibrosis patient - Mucoid (capsular) strains
  5. Ear and eye infections
  6. Green nail syndrome
  7. Shanghai fever

questions.text: A 35 yrs old farmer got himself stung by a bee while walking on his fields. Then he devolved anaphylaxis within few mins and all are mediators except:
questions.solution:
Anaphylaxis is a severe allergic reaction (HSR-1) triggered by the release of chemical mediators from mast cells and basophils. The release of these mediators leads to a rapid increase in vascular permeability, vasodilation, and smooth muscle contraction, contributing to the symptoms of anaphylaxis.

Primary Mediators Action

  1. Histamine, Heparin and Serotonin- ↑Vascular permeability, ↑Smooth-muscle contraction
  2. Eosinophil chemotactic factor & Neutrophil chemotactic factor
  3. Proteases- Bronchial mucus secretion; Degradation of blood-vessel basement membrane

Secondary Mediators

  • Platelet activating factor- Platelet aggregation and degranulation; Contraction of pulmonary smooth muscles
  • Leukotrienes- ↑ Vascular permeability; Contraction of pulmonary smooth muscles
  • Prostaglandins- ↑Vasodilation; Contraction of pulmonary smooth muscles; Platelet aggregation
  • Bradykinin- ↑Vascular permeability; Smooth-muscle contraction
  • Cytokines (IL-1 and TNF-α)- Systemic anaphylaxis

choices.text: Noncritical items also included in classification
Cardiac catheter, e.g. of critical items

questions.text: Which is false about Spaulding classification?

choices.text: Promotes growth of Staphylococcus, Streptococcus and Candida

questions.text: Urine culture on CLED medium is used in preference to MacConkey agar in UTI suspected patients as?
questions.solution:
CLED & MacConkey agar both are the differential culture media. They differentiate LF from NLF bacteria.

CLED & MacConkey agar both media inhibits the swarming.

MacConkey agar only allows grow of GNB as it contains bile salts which inhibits the growth of gram-positive bacteria.

CLED agar support both types of bacteria (gram positive and negative) including candida therefore it more preferred over MA for the isolation of uropathogens.

questions.text: A fungus is isolated from a blood culture of a patient who travelled to southeast Asia. Isolated fungi produced red pigment that diffused into the media. Probable causative fungus is?
questions.solution:
1. Talaromyces marneffei is a thermally dimorphic fungus that causes opportunistic infection in HIV infected patients.
  2. The bamboo rats are reservoirs of infection.
  3. Transmission is by inhalation of conidia from the environment.
  4. T. marneffei produces two types of clinical manifestations
    • Systemic infection: similar to systemic histoplasmosis
    • Warty lesions mimicking that of Molluscum contagiosum are seen
  5. The Mold form bas a characteristic brick red pigment but the microscopic appearance of mold form is similar to other Penicillium species.

choices.text: Its germ tube positive like Candida albicans
It's a GPOBYC in gram stain

questions.text: Which statement is not correct about Candida auris?
questions.solution:
Candida auris is an emerging fungal pathogen that is associated with nosocomial infections and is considered a serious global health threat. It has numerous virulence qualities and shows multi-drug resistance patterns to common antifungal therapy used for other invasive Candida infections.

Yeast identification methods employed by laboratories typically misidentify C.auris as other yeasts making the detection and control of this pathogen difficult.

C.auris is a budding yeast with cells that may be single, in pairs, or in groups.

C.aurisrarely forms hyphae or pseudohyphae, nor does it form germ tubes.

On CHROMagar, colonies of C.auris may display multiple color morphs ranging from pale to dark pink and rarely beige.

questions.text: A Covid 19 patient suffers from ARDS and it was on prolong corticosteroids. She was initially diagnosed with Rhino-zygomycosis as blacking of the tissues as shown in image. Microscopic examination of black tissues, reveal the infection been caused by with fungi with aseptate and broad hyphae. Which of the following fungus is responsible for this infection?
questions.solution:
Broad aseptate hyphe: Belongs to the family zygomycetes or Phycomycetes, e.g. Rhizopus, Mucor, Absidia, Apophysomyces

Narrow septate hyphae, e.g. Aspergillus (belongs to Ascomycetes), Penicillium, Fusarium, Dermetophytes


Zygomycosis or mucormycosis represents group of life-threatening infections caused by aseptate fungi belonging to the phylum zygomycota. Examples include: Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Common manifestations:

  • Rhinocerebral mucormycosis
  • Pulmonary mucormycosis

Predisposing factors: Agents of mucormycosis require iron as growth factor. Hence conditions with increased iron load are at higher risk of developing invasive mucormycosis, such as:

  • Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is the most important risk factor
  • End stage renal disease
  • Patients taking iron therapy or deferoxamine (iron chelator)
  • Defects in phagocytic functions (e.g. neutropenia or steroid therapy).

Culture on SDA at 25°C reveals cottony woolly colonies which are initially white, later become brown black due to sporulation giving rise to salt and pepper appearance

questions.text: A 24yrs old patient following frequent use of contact lens, developed corneal ulcers and symptoms of conjunctivitis. Saline mount preparation of corneal scrapping shows both cyst and trophozoites. What should be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Acanthamoeba is a genus of protozoans widely present in various habitats, including water, air, soil, and dust. Acanthamoeba is a free-living amoeba and causes:

  • Granulomatous amebic encephalitis
  • Ulcerative keratitis

Acanthamoeba species exists in nature as cyst and trophozoite forms. Th ere is no flagellated form. Trophozoite is characterized by acanthopodia. Cyst has two layers with an outer wrinkled ectocyst. Calcofluor stain: It is recommended to visualize the double walled cyst.

Indirect fluorescent antibody technique (IFAT) with specifi c antisera can be used for speciation of Acanthamoeba.

Acanthamoeba keratitis (AK) is a rare but often misdiagnosed corneal infection, primarily affecting contact lens wearers and occasionally resulting from corneal trauma in non-contact lens users. This infection is caused by the Acanthamoeba genus, a globally widespread unicellular protozoan parasite. Key risk factors include trauma, swimming in contaminated water, contact lens use in showers, lack of hygiene, and using contaminated lens solutions.

questions.text: A 28yrs old commercial sex worker had copious, yellow-green, frothy vagina discharge with a fishy Odor. On further examination she had also Strawberry cervix. What would be the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
Trichomonas vaginalis (Genital Flagellates)

Most Common parasitic cause of STD and nongonococcal urethritis.

Habitat: Urethra, vagina and prostate.

Infective stage and diagnostic stage: Trophozoites

Clinical manifestation

Incubation period: 4-28 days

In men: Asymptomatic or Urethritis, Prostatitis and Cystitis

In women: Asymptomatic or vulvo-vaginitis-Characterized by:

  • Profuse vaginal discharge with offensive smell,
  • High pH (> 4.5)
  • Smell gets accentuated by adding 10% KOH (whiff test)
  • Strawberry vaginal mucosa (Colpitis macularis)

questions.text: Your patient is a 40-year-old man with occasional mild right upper abdominal discomfort but is otherwise well. On examination, his liver is enlarged. An MRI reveals a cystic mass in the liver. On questioning, he says that he was born and raised in rural area on a sheep ranch and came to Delhi 10 years ago. Of the following, which one is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Echinococcus granulosus: Dog tape worm

Definitive host: Dog and wild carnivores.

Intermediate hosts: Man and other herbivorous animals.

Man is an accidental host (dead end).

Eggs: Infective stage of the parasite.

Eggs transform to larva (hydatid cyst) that penetrate GIT and migrates to various organs like liver.

Hydatid disease: Hepatomegaly (60-70% of cases), then lungs.

Diagnosis

  • Hydatid fluid microscopy:
    • Wet mount examination to demonstrates protoscolices and brood capsule
    • Acid fast staining of centrifuged deposit
    • Histological examination
  • Casoni's skin test: Immediate hypersensitivity reaction (Type 1)
  • Imaging methods: USG, MRI and X-ray: Demonstrates size, exact location and extension of the cysts
  • Water lily sign in USG: Due to collapsed cyst (floating membrane) floating in the abdomen

choices.text: NS1 antigen detection by ICT or ELISA
Viral culture and isolation in cell line
ICT or ELISA for antibody against Dengue virus

questions.text: A 35yrs old male presented in OPD with high fever, severe headache, pain behind the eyes, severe muscle and joint pain from 3days. all of these are acceptable investigations at day 3 of presentation except:
questions.solution:
Laboratory Diagnosis

1. NS1 antigen detection: ELISA and ICT are available for detecting NS1 antigen in serum.

  • Early detection: NS1 antigen becomes detectable from day-1 of fever and remains positive up to 18 days.
  • Highly specific: It differentiates between flaviviruses. It can also be specific to different dengue serotypes.

2. Antibody detection:

  • In primary infection: IgM appears first after 5 days of fever and disappears within 90 days, followed by IgG (14-21 days of illness).
  • In secondary infection: Four-fold rise of IgG antibody titers occurs.
  • MAC: ELISA is the most recommended test with excellent sensitivity and specificity. It can detect IgM and IgG separately.

3. Virus detection: Dengue virus can be detected in blood from 1 day before the onset of symptoms and 5 days thereafter. It is done by:

  • Virus isolation can be done by inoculation into mosquito cell line or in mouse
  • Detection of specific genes of viral RNA by real time RT- PCR.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man underwent kidney transplantation. Two months after transplantation, he developed fever and feature suggestive of bilateral diffuse interstitial pneumonitis. Which of the following is most likely etiologic agent?
questions.solution:
Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is a significant concern for kidney or solid organs transplant recipients due to the immunosuppression caused by medications. Patients receiving chemotherapy, and AIDS are also at high risk. CMV infection can lead to various complications, including increased risk of rejection, graft failure, and other infections. While many infections are asymptomatic, it's crucial to monitor for symptoms like fever, diarrhea, and unexplained creatinine increases, as these can indicate CMV infection.

  • Diffuse Interstitial Pneumonia is the most common complication of CMV infection.

Laboratory Diagnosis

  • CMV produces both perinuclear cytoplasmic and intranuclear inclusions (describe as Owl's eye appearance).
  • Antigen detection: pp65 antigen detection by ELISA.
  • Antibody detection: IgM is indicative of active infection
  • PCR

questions.text: A 35-year-old male veterinary doctor is seen in the emergency complaining of severe headache and vomiting that began last night. His temperature is 40°C. While in the ER, he is increasingly combative and has a grand mal seizure. He is "foaming at the mouth" and cannot drink any liquids. Analysis of his spinal fluid reveals no abnormality, and no organisms are seen in the Gram stain. Two days later, despite supportive measures, he dies. Pathologic examination of the brain reveals eosinophilic inclusion bodies in the cytoplasm of neurons. Which of the following is most likely etiologic agent?
questions.solution:
RABIES VIRUS is a Bullet-shaped, enveloped virus.

Transmission: Rabies virus is usually transmitted to humans by the bite of an infected animal.

Clinical Manifestations

Incubation period: 1-3 month (20-90 days)

Encephalitis: Hydrophobia, aerophobia and hyper excitability Hydrophobia is due to dysfunction of infected brainstem neurons. The act of swallowing precipitates an involuntary, painful spasm of the respiratory muscles.

ANS dysfunction: Hypersalivation (foaming at the mouth), gooseflesh, arrhythmia and priapism Lucid interval gradually decrease.

Diagnosis

Rabies antigen detection

  • Direct IF test detecting rabies nucleoprotein antigens in specimens. The best specimen is hair follicle of nape of neck (most sensitive).
  • Corneal impression smear: Positive in late stage

Negri body detection

  • Negri body detection is used for post mortem diagnosis.
  • They are intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions.
  • MC sites are neurons of cerebellum and hippocampus.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl was well until about 3 weeks ago, when she began complaining of being "tired all the time." On examination, her temperature is 38°C and there is tenderness below the right knee. Hemoglobin: 10.2; WBC: 9600 with increased neutrophils. A sickle cell prep shows a moderate sickling tendency. She was diagnosed with osteomyelitis. Of the following, which one is the MOST likely cause?
questions.solution:
Sickle cell osteomyelitis is a dangerous infection of the bone that is more common in people with sickle cell disease (SCD). It's an infection that can be difficult to diagnose because its symptoms can be similar to those of vaso-occlusive crises (VOC), which are common in SCD. Early and accurate diagnosis is crucial to prevent bone destruction and deformity, as osteomyelitis can lead to chronic issues, bone deformities, and even sepsis if not treated promptly.

Sickle cell osteomyelitis is most commonly caused by Salmonella.

questions.text: Your patient is a 30-year-old man with low-grade perineal pain for several weeks who had an episode of painful ejaculation and postcoital hematuria yesterday. He is in a long-standing monogamous relationship. He has traveled extensively throughout the world during the past 10 years. Urinalysis and urine culture were negative. Cytologic examination of cells in the urine revealed no tumor cells. Cystoscopy revealed several polypoid lesions, and a biopsy of a lesion was taken. The tissue was examined in the light microscope, and eggs with a terminal spine were seen. Of the following, which one is the MOST likely cause?
questions.solution:
Schistosoma haematobium - (Blood Fluke)

Resides in: Vesical and pelvic venous plexus

Egg has terminal spine

Associated with:

  • Hematuria
  • Hydroureter and hydronephrosis
  • Bladder Carcinoma
